description.narrative:
Access to finance and markets: The project will continue to have significant positive impacts on the main stakeholder groups, and especially on coffee farmers and surrounding communities. The farmers should continue to benefit from reliable access to markets and in select cases access to finance and training provided by the group, particularly in regions where financing has become challenging. The Company's activity is benefiting the producers directly as it purchases their products and provides them with financing, certification, logistics, and forward price fixing.
Inclusive: With more than 20% of Mercon's global supply from farms of less than 5 hectares, the investment is classified as inclusive in terms of reach to smallholder farmers.
IFC expects the project, through the complimentary IFC Advisory Services project (#604064), to help farmers in Nicaragua improve their Robusta coffee production, with better quality and higher yields. This is also expected to introduce practices to strengthen the sustainability of coffee production.
Integration: IFC expects the facility, through the demonstration and replication channel, to contribute to the strengthening of financial integration of the coffee value chain, in the markets where Mercon operates. This is essentially achieved through maintaining connections between several private sector financial institutions and coffee farmers, cooperatives, suppliers and aggregators.

Headquartered in the Netherlands, Mercon Coffee Group (Mercon) is a vertically integrated global green coffee supplier. Mercon is among the leading coffee suppliers in the world and has extensive experience in farming, production, trading, marketing, logistics and risk management in the coffee industry. With 65 years of experience, Mercon sources green coffee from major coffee-producing regions and merchandizes and supplies it to leading coffee roasters on a global basis. This proposed investment consists of a revolving credit facility of up to US$60 million by IFC (the Facility), which includes up to US$18 million from the Private Sector Window of Global Agriculture and Food Security Program (GAFSP) with focus on Nicaragua in favor of Mercon. The proposed investment aims to support the coffee sector value chain from production and storage in IDA countries in Central America (Nicaragua, Honduras) and other producing countries (Brazil, Guatemala, Vietnam) to commercialization in multiple destinations.
